awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Solid Earth response of the Patagonian Andes to post-Little Ice Age glacial retreat
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how the Earth responds to a cryospheric mass imbalance on
a time scale of centuries in a compact, well-monitored region of Patagonia, a region of complex Neogene ridge subduction and youthful volcanism. The problem of glacial isostatic adjustment (GIA) is an important problem and critical to understanding the viscosity and time-scales of deformation in the upper mantle. The PI team will try to quantify and model the isostatic response to ice and sediment loading and unloading.   A primary driver of modern rock uplift beneath and surrounding the Southern Patagonia Icefield (SPI) is interpreted to be ice loss following the peak advances of the Little Ice Age (LIA). Recent geodetic studies reveal remarkably rapid uplift rates (up to 40 mm/yr and averaging ~20 mm/yr around the SPI). These rates are the fastest modern geologic uplift rates; ones that demand a low viscosity mantle. In Patagonia, the presence of a somewhat poorly understood slab window that developed during Late Cenozoic time supports speculation that a low-viscosity zone underlies the region where GIA is very
rapid.

This team will explore the causes of high rates and spatial-temporal pattern of the inferred GIA using: (1) a regional broadband seismological array to delineate the crustal and upper mantle structure and viscosity and observe seismicity (currently undefined) along the subducting Austral slab; (2) shipboard reflection seismic data and sediment cores to image and date the young pro- and subglacial sediments deposited in the glacial troughs (now fiord-like lakes) carved by advancing ice with a goal of defining both the geometry of ice and volume of deposited sediment through time; (3) new mapping and dating of the subaerial morainal sequence to define the time-varying spatial geometry of the SPI along its two largest outlet glaciers; and (4) improved geophysical models of glacier and solid earth responses.

por.por_cntn:
Southern Patagonia embodies extremes. Its icefields are the largest in the southern hemisphere outside of Antarctica. Its surface uplift rates, augmented by glacial isostatic adjustment, may be the fastest in the world. It hosts the world's largest ice-contact lakes. Its climate transitions from humid to arid across the slim kilometers of the spine of the Andes, juxtaposing glaciers and forest against deglaciated desert. Its landforms and deposits hold an accessible and near-complete record of Pleistocene glaciation. From these glaciers and lakes emanates the Rio Santa Cruz, a winding blue watercourse dividing these eastern deserts. Above these plains stand active volcanoes, encompassed within or emerging from the icefields.

 

The Minnesota-centered portion of the team within this collaborative, multi-institutional project probed the past and present of this unique region, focusing on Lago Argentino and its adjoining icefields and terrestrial landscapes. This work required us to expand and invent techniques, cross hundreds of kilometers on land and water, build and analyze a chronology of the geological past, and analyze samples and data sets to map and reconstruct environmental change. To make this possible, we built a robust international collaboration with Argentine and Chilean scientists.

 

We developed and expanded three major technologies to enable this research. First, we developed a new launch and recovery system supporting deep-water gravity coring from vessels of opportunity, now available to future CSD Facility users. Second, we advanced and implemented lightweight and open-source sensor technologies to monitor weather and ablation on modern glaciers. Third, we built robust image-analysis toolkits to perform varve counts and characterize their precision, and to map ice velocities.

 

With these capabilities in hand, our team retrieved what we believe to be the most spatially comprehensive library of cores from any ice-contact lake studied to date globally. The 108 meters of core recovered from 45 sites (water depths as great as 630 meters) represent environments ranging from the deep brazos (fjords) adjacent to actively calving ice fronts, to the vast and bathymetrically complex main lake basin, to  lake-margin areas influenced by non-glaciated watersheds and sediment sources. This spatial and bathymetric breadth of sampling, coupled with the semi-automated varve-counting tool developed by Van Wyk De Vries, has allowed us to analyze critical questions of sediment sourcing and intralake depositional  mechanisms, as well as support the SMU active-seismics group in evaluating mass transport of eroded  sub-glacial material. 

 

On land and ice, we measured modern glacier mass loss while also constraining past glacier extent. Our sensor data from our in-house-developed open-source weather and ablation stations add modern and location-specific information on ice–climate interactions. We expanded this modern-data approach to assess the hydrological balance of all glaciers in the Lago Argentino basin. By sampling boulders from glacial moraines and buried sands from ancient outwash plains – formed by broad rivers emanating from glaciers, we expanded and extended the glacial chronology. We dated late Holocene (Little Ice Age) ice margins from  Glacier Upsala, the rapidly retreating largest outlet glacier of the Southern Patagonian Icefield. We extended our chronological efforts through and east of Lago Argentino. Sediment cores place the Little Ice Age and prior Holocene-age events in context and help us to connect volcanic activity, glacial isostatic adjustment, and past climate. From older moraines and outwash, we produced a chronology of the past two glacial cycles in the Lago Argentino region.

 

To augment these field data, we developed two key image-analysis tools: (1) Glacier Image Velocimetry and (2) countMYvarves. Both techniques used image cross-correlation to generate data sets on Earth-surface processes. Glacier Image Velocimetry (GIV) provides a straightforward tool to produce ice-surface-velocity fields. While velocity-field extraction follows known methods, GIV's tools and simplicity broaden applicability and may improve accuracy. These attributes enabled us to map ice velocities through the Southern Patagonian Icefield and, in an extension to this project, to apply velocity maps to find volumes of glacial ice on tropical Andean volcanoes. CountMYvarves brings modern image-analysis approaches to the over-a-century-long tradition of using annually laminated sediments to develop geological chronologies. It enabled us to date and compare the large number of cores extracted from Lago Argentino. Both tools will continue to advance science beyond this project.

 

In sum, we reconstructed the past and present of the Lago Argentino basin, with applications to the broader collaborative project goals of understanding glacial isostatic deformation and ice–climate–solid-Earth interactions. We mapped and modeled changes in ice-sheet extent over time scales from years to hundreds of thousands of years. We found climatic cyclicities and volcanic eruption histories in laminated sediments. We designed and expanded remote-sensing, in-situ monitoring, and sample-retrieval techniques. And we built all of our work into and through a multi-national collaboration that continues to grow research and community through the next generation of scientists. Through all of this, we significantly advanced southern hemisphere cryospheric science while building structures and capacity for future discoveries.
